questions.text: An Index of operational efficiency of the malaria control program is
questions.solution:
• B. Annual blood examination rate (ABER):
    • This is the percentage of the population tested for malaria through blood smears or diagnostic tests.
    • While useful for monitoring surveillance efforts, it doesn't directly reflect the outcome of control efforts.High ABER may indicate increased screening, but not necessarily reduced transmission

Why Not Others?

  • Annual Parasite Incidence (API):
    • Number of confirmed malaria cases per 1,000 population in a given year.
    • A low API indicates that malaria transmission is under control, while a high API signals the need for more intensive interventions.
    • Provides a clear picture of the overall malaria burden in a region.
    • Helps to monitor trends over time and the impact of malaria control programs.
    • Used to compare regions and track progress in reducing malaria incidence
  • C. Slide positivity rate (SPR):
    • The proportion of positive slides among all tested samples.
    • Indicates the intensity of malaria transmission but doesn't reflect the overall control program efficiency.
    • SPR can fluctuate based on testing frequency and population characteristics.
  • D. Infant parasite rate:
    • Measures the proportion of infants testing positive for malaria.
    • While important for understanding the impact on vulnerable groups, it's not a direct indicator of operational efficiency across the population.

Key Takeaways: The index of operational efficiency of a malaria control program is often measured by the Annual Blood Examination Rate (ABER). This rate provides an indication of the extent to which malaria surveillance activities, such as blood examinations for malaria parasites, are being carried out in a population.

questions.text: Mass Drug Administration on a single day is a strategy used in control of
questions.solution:
• Mass Drug Administration (MDA) on a single day is crucial in Lymphatic Filariasis (LF) control.
  • Objective: The aim is to reduce the parasite load and interrupt transmission by treating entire populations in endemic regions.
  • Drugs used: Typically include diethylcarbamazine (DEC), albendazole, and in some areas, ivermectin combined with albendazole.
  • WHO's Global Programme: MDA is part of the Global Programme to Eliminate Lymphatic Filariasis (GPELF), designed to eliminate LF as a public health problem.
  • MDA targets entire communities (even asymptomatic individuals), aiming to reduce microfilariae (early stage parasite) in the population and stop mosquito transmission.

Why Not Others?

  • B. Malaria: Mass drug administration is not the primary strategy for malaria. Malaria control focuses on vector control, diagnosis, treatment, and prevention methods like bed nets and antimalarial drugs, rather than population-wide treatment on a single day.
  • C. Trachoma: Control strategies for trachoma focus on surgery, antibiotics, facial cleanliness, and environmental improvement, rather than MDA on a single day.
  • D. Night blindness: Typically caused by vitamin A deficiency, night blindness is addressed by supplementation rather than population-wide drug administration.

Key Takeaways:

  • MDA for LF is a proven strategy for interrupting transmission and reducing disease burden.
  • DEC and albendazole are commonly used drugs in MDA for LF.
  • Global efforts have led to successful elimination of LF in some regions.

choices.text: Skin caring by washing and drying
Lymph drainage by elevating the limb
Reduce the further spread of disease

questions.text: All of the following regarding the management of lymphoedema are correct EXCEPT
questions.solution:
• Early detection of cases: Early detection allows for timely intervention, preventing complications such as infections and progressive swelling.
  • Skin caring by washing and drying: Proper skin care, including washing and drying, helps prevent infections, which are common in lymphoedema patients due to the compromised lymphatic system.
  • Lymph drainage by elevating the limb: Elevating the affected limb improves lymphatic fluid drainage and reduces swelling, which is key to managing lymphoedema.
  • Reduce the further spread of disease: Incorrect. Lymphoedema does not "spread" like an infectious disease. It results from lymphatic dysfunction, causing fluid buildup, but it is not infectious.

Why Not Others:

  • Early detection: Crucial in managing lymphoedema and avoiding further complications.
  • Skin care: Essential for preventing skin infections, a common concern in lymphoedema patients.
  • Limb elevation: A key management strategy to enhance lymphatic drainage and control swelling.

Key Takeaways:

  • Lymphoedema is a condition resulting from lymphatic dysfunction, not an infection.
  • Management focuses on controlling swelling, preventing infections, and improving lymphatic drainage.
  • It is important to address early detection, skin care, and drainage techniques for effective management.

choices.text: In 1940-1978 disease spread with epidemics in China, Korea and India
1983-1987 Vaccine available in US on investigational basis

questions.text: True about history of Japanese encephalitis is EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• A. In 1940-1978 disease spread with epidemics in China, Korea, and India: Correct. Japanese encephalitis (JE) spread across Asia, with significant epidemics in China, Korea, and India during this period.
  • B. In 1983 immunization in South Korea: Correct. South Korea introduced JE immunization in 1983 to control the disease and reduce outbreaks.
  • C. 1983-1987 Vaccine available in the US on an investigational basis: Correct. Between 1983 and 1987, the JE vaccine was available in the US on an investigational basis as a part of research trials to assess its effectiveness.
  • D. In 1980 vaccine available in India: Incorrect. The JE vaccine was not available in India in 1980. The vaccine was introduced in India in the late 1990s, and its widespread use started in 2006.

Why Not Others:

  • A. Disease spread in Asia: Historically, JE spread across several Asian countries, including China, Korea, and India, from 1940-1978.
  • B. Immunization in South Korea: South Korea was one of the early countries to implement immunization programs for JE in 1983.
  • C. Vaccine availability in the US (1983-1987): The US had an investigational vaccine for JE, marking an important step in research and preparedness against potential outbreaks.

Key Takeaways:

  • JE outbreaks were prominent in Asia, with significant spread until the 1970s.
  • Immunization programs began in South Korea in the early 1980s.
  • The JE vaccine was not introduced in India until the late 1990s, and its widespread use began around 2006.

choices.text: Percent houses in a locality with confirmed larval breeding places of Aedes aegypti
Percent Aedes mosquitoes on dissection showing the presence of yellow fever viruses
Number of female Aedes mosquitoes present in 100 square meters area
Number of Aedes mosquitoes per 100 total mosquitoes caught in 1 hour

questions.text: Aedes aegypti index means
questions.solution:
• A. Percent houses in a locality with confirmed larval breeding places of Aedes aegypti: Correct. The Aedes aegypti index measures the proportion of houses in a locality that have confirmed breeding sites for Aedes aegypti mosquitoes, the primary vector for diseases like dengue, chikungunya, and yellow fever.
  • B. Percent Aedes mosquitoes on dissection showing the presence of yellow fever viruses: Incorrect. This would refer to a measure of infection in mosquitoes, not the breeding index.
  • C. Number of female Aedes mosquitoes present in 100 square meters area: Incorrect. This does not describe the Aedes aegypti index, which is concerned with breeding sites, not the number of mosquitoes in a given area.
  • D. Number of Aedes mosquitoes per 100 total mosquitoes caught in 1 hour: Incorrect. This relates to the overall proportion of Aedes mosquitoes in a sample, not to the breeding index.

Why Not Others:

  • B. Virus presence in mosquitoes: This is a separate diagnostic measure, not part of the Aedes aegypti index.
  • C. Number of mosquitoes per area: This describes mosquito density, not the Aedes aegypti breeding index.
  • D. Proportion of Aedes mosquitoes in a catch: This is a measure of mosquito distribution, not breeding site presence.

Key Takeaways:

  • The Aedes aegypti index is used to monitor the risk of mosquito-borne diseases by identifying breeding sites in homes.
  • It helps in assessing the effectiveness of vector control measures and guiding prevention efforts.

choices.text: No specific treatment only oral rehydration and antipyretics
Any superimposed bacterial infection should be treated
Intensive supportive therapy with intravenous fluid, blood, plasma or plasma substitutes

questions.text: True about treatment of yellow fever is EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• No specific treatment for yellow fever; management focuses on supportive care, including oral rehydration and antipyretics for symptom relief.
  • Secondary bacterial infections should be treated with appropriate antibiotics.
  • Severe cases require intensive supportive therapy, such as intravenous fluids, blood transfusions, and plasma substitutes to manage dehydration, blood loss, and liver dysfunction.
  • No antiviral treatment is available for yellow fever; supportive care remains the primary focus.

Key Takeaways:

choices.text: Given intramuscular as 1 ml to adults and 0.5 ml to infants
Reconstituted vaccine if not used must be discarded within half an hour

questions.text: All the following are true about vaccine used in yellow fever EXCEPT
questions.solution:
• Stored between + 5 to –30°C: Correct. The yellow fever vaccine is stored at temperatures between +2°C and +8°C, but it can tolerate short-term exposure to lower temperatures (down to –30°C).
  • Live attenuated freeze-dried vaccine: Correct. The vaccine is a live attenuated virus in freeze-dried form for stability, which is reconstituted before use.
  • Given intramuscular as 1 ml to adults and 0.5 ml to infants: Incorrect. The vaccine is administered subcutaneously, not intramuscularly, and the standard dose is 0.5 ml for both adults and infants.
  • Reconstituted vaccine if not used must be discarded within half an hour: Correct. After reconstitution, the vaccine must be used within 30 minutes, as its potency decreases rapidly.

Key Takeaways:

  • The yellow fever vaccine is stored at +2°C to +8°C, reconstituted before use, and administered subcutaneously.
  • After reconstitution, the vaccine must be used within 30 minutes to maintain its effectiveness.
  • 0.5 ml is the standard dose for both adults and infants, not 1 ml.

choices.text: Temephos to kill immature aquatic stages
Abate: Can prevent breeding up to 3 months
Source reduction measures through minor engineering
Use of deltamethrin soaked bed nets

questions.text: True about anti-larval measures (mosquito) are EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Temephos to kill immature aquatic stages: Correct. Temephos is an insecticide used to target mosquito larvae in water, preventing their development into adults.
  • Abate: Can prevent breeding up to 3 months: Correct. Abate is a larvicide that can control mosquito larvae for an extended period, up to 3 months.
  • Source reduction measures through minor engineering: Correct. Source reduction, such as modifying or eliminating breeding habitats, is a key approach to controlling mosquito populations.
  • Use of deltamethrin soaked bed nets: Incorrect. Deltamethrin-soaked bed nets are used as an adulticide measure to prevent mosquito bites, not as an anti-larval measure. The question is focused on larval control, so this option does not fit.

Key Takeaways:

choices.text: Inactivated, mouse brain derived vaccine to animals and human
Tick control with acaricides in live stock farms
Personal protective measures in endemic areas

questions.text: What is most appropriate and effective means for prevention and control of CCHF:
questions.solution:
• Inactivated, mouse brain-derived vaccine to animals and humans: Incorrect. While research is ongoing, the inactivated, mouse-brain-derived vaccine is not widely available or considered the most effective control method.
  • Tick control with acaricides in livestock farms: Incorrect. Tick control can help reduce transmission in animals, but it does not comprehensively address human prevention, as CCHF also spreads via human-to-human contact and direct exposure to infected bodily fluids.
  • Personal protective measures in endemic areas: Correct. The most effective method for preventing CCHF is the use of personal protective equipment (PPE), such as gloves, masks, gowns, and eye protection, especially when handling livestock, patients, or deceased individuals in endemic regions.
  • Chemoprophylaxis to persons with suspected exposure: Incorrect. There is no established chemoprophylaxis for CCHF, and prevention primarily focuses on personal protective measures rather than medication.

Key Takeaways:

  • The most effective prevention for CCHF is the use of personal protective measures (PPE) in endemic areas.
  • Tick control and vaccines play a role in controlling animal-to-human transmission but do not address human-to-human spread directly.
  • Chemoprophylaxis is not a recommended preventive approach for CCHF.

choices.text: First reported in China in farmers in 1885
First reported in 1883 in sewage workers in Japan
Regional reference lab is located at Port Blair (A and N Islands)
Seasonal outbreaks are regularly reported from Maharashtra, Karnataka and Andhra Pradesh

questions.text: True about leptospirosis EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Leptospirosis is a zoonotic disease caused by the bacterium Leptospira, typically transmitted through contact with water contaminated by urine from infected animals.
  • Historically, first identified in Japan (1883) in sewage workers due to its association with occupational exposure.
  • In India, the Port Blair lab specializes in leptospirosis diagnostics, research, and outbreak management.
  • Seasonal outbreaks are linked to monsoons, as floods facilitate the spread of the bacteria in waterlogged areas.
  • High-risk groups include farmers, sewage workers, and individuals in flood-prone areas.

Why Not Others?

  • B. First reported in 1883 in sewage workers in Japan: Correct, as Japan documented the first cases of leptospirosis in 1883.
  • C. Regional reference lab is located at Port Blair (A and N Islands): Correct, recognized as a nodal center for diagnosis and research on leptospirosis in India.
  • D. Seasonal outbreaks are regularly reported from Maharashtra, Karnataka, and Andhra Pradesh: Correct, monsoon seasons in these states frequently lead to outbreaks of leptospirosis.

Key Takeaways

  • Leptospirosis transmission: Contact with contaminated water or soil, especially after heavy rainfall or floods.
  • Geographic relevance: Frequently reported in tropical and subtropical regions, including India.
  • Occupational hazard: Common in farmers, sewage workers, and those exposed to contaminated water.
  • Prevention: Improved sanitation, protective measures during floods, and early diagnosis can reduce outbreaks.

choices.text: Isolation of leptospira from blood (during illness) and urine (after 1 week)

questions.text: True about gold standard test for diagnosis of leptospirosis used during outbreaks is
questions.solution:
• The Microscopic Agglutination Test (MAT) is the gold standard due to its high sensitivity, specificity, and ability to identify the infecting serovar.
  • MAT procedure: The patient’s serum is mixed with various serovars of Leptospira antigens, and agglutination is observed under a microscope, indicating the presence of specific antibodies.
  • It requires paired sera samples (acute and convalescent phases) to confirm rising antibody titers.
  • While reliable, MAT is time-intensive, needs live antigens and specialized laboratories, making it less feasible for routine use outside outbreak scenarios.
  • Rapid diagnostic tests (e.g., ELISA) are often used initially, but MAT remains the definitive test.

Why Not Others?

  • B. Dark ground microscopy: Limited utility due to low sensitivity; detects spirochetes directly in fluids but often yields false negatives.
  • C. Isolation of leptospira from blood (during illness) and urine (after 1 week): Though confirmatory, this is slow and labor-intensive, requiring up to weeks to yield results.
  • D. Culture of spirochetes: Highly specific but impractical during outbreaks due to the prolonged growth time (6–8 weeks) and need for specialized media like EMJH.

Key Takeaways

  • MAT: Most accurate for diagnosing leptospirosis; critical during outbreaks for confirming cases.
  • Challenges of MAT: Requires specialized resources and expertise, making it less suitable for widespread use in resource-limited settings.
  • Complementary Tests: ELISA and PCR are faster alternatives for initial screening, but MAT remains the diagnostic benchmark.
  • Public Health Role: Essential in outbreak management for identifying serovars and guiding interventions.

questions.text: Best single test for rapid diagnosis of rabies is
questions.solution:
• Fluorescent Antibody Test (FAT):
    • Detects rabies virus antigens in tissue samples such as brain tissue (animals) or skin biopsies (humans).
    • Provides results within 2-4 hours, making it the fastest and most reliable diagnostic method.
    • Has a high sensitivity (>95%) and specificity (>99%) for confirming rabies infection.
    • Requires a fluorescence microscope and skilled personnel, limiting its application in resource-limited settings.
  • Commonly used tissues:
    • Animals: Brainstem, hippocampus, and cerebellum.
    • Humans: Nuchal skin biopsies, where hair follicles contain virus-infected nerve endings.
  • Advantage: Helps in early detection to guide post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) decisions or animal quarantine measures.

Why Not Others?

  • B. Microscopic examination:
    • Detects Negri bodies (viral inclusion bodies) in brain tissue but is less sensitive and often unreliable in early or atypical cases.
  • C. Mouse inoculation test:
    • Involves inoculating mice with suspected rabies tissue and observing for symptoms, but it is time-consuming (weeks) and ethically controversial.
  • D. Corneal test:
    • Detects viral antigens in corneal impressions but has lower sensitivity and is rarely used with the availability of FAT and molecular methods like PCR.

Key Takeaways

  • FAT: The gold standard for rapid rabies diagnosis, providing quick and accurate results.
  • Practical application: Early and accurate detection ensures timely PEP or public health interventions.
  • Limitations: Requires specialized equipment and expertise, but its advantages outweigh these in critical scenarios.
  • Future potential: Molecular tests like PCR complement FAT for virus detection in early or challenging cases.

choices.text: Elimination of stray dogs combined with their mass immunization

questions.text: Most logical and cost effective approach for control of urban rabies is
questions.solution:
• Elimination of stray dogs and mass immunization:
    • Stray dogs are the primary reservoirs and transmitters of rabies in urban areas.
    • Mass canine vaccination creates herd immunity, drastically reducing the risk of rabies transmission.
    • This combined strategy addresses both disease prevention and population control, making it the most cost-effective and practical method.
    • Sterilization programs often accompany this approach to reduce stray dog populations sustainably.
  • Global evidence: Countries like Mexico and Sri Lanka have shown significant reductions in rabies cases by implementing mass dog vaccination programs without resorting to indiscriminate culling.

Why Not Others?

  • B. Registration of all domestic dogs:
    • Helps identify and monitor pets but does not address the stray dog population, which is a major reservoir for rabies.
  • C. Quarantine for about one year:
    • Impractical and resource-intensive in urban settings with large stray dog populations.
    • More suitable for specific rabies-exposed animals, not as a broad strategy.
  • D. Health education:
    • Crucial for human awareness about rabies prevention and post-exposure prophylaxis but does not directly control rabies transmission in animal populations.

Key Takeaways

  • Primary reservoirs: Stray dogs are the leading sources of urban rabies transmission.
  • Cost-effective strategy: Eliminating stray dogs and vaccinating them is the most logical and impactful method for control.
  • Integrated approach: Sustainable rabies control includes dog sterilization, mass immunization, and public awareness.

choices.text: Periodic mass deworming at 2-3 months intervals alone can finally lead to eradication of hookworm infestation
Soil contamination by open field defecation and ingestion of infective larvae is the main route of spread of hookworm infestation
A dudoneale is the only species prevalent in India and responsible for disease
Chandler index is important indicator to assess the load of hook worm infestation in a given community

questions.text: Which of the following statement about hook worm infestations is correct?
questions.solution:
• Chandler Index:
    • Assesses community hookworm burden based on egg density in feces, providing a quantifiable measure of infection intensity.
    • There is a term called as Chandler's Index which is the average number of hookworm eggs per gram of feces for the entire community. ( > 300: Public health problem)29 Mar 2024
    • Helps evaluate the effectiveness of control programs, such as deworming and sanitation campaigns.
  • Hookworm Transmission:
    • The infective larvae (filariform stage) penetrate the skin, typically through bare feet, and migrate to the intestines.
    • Found in areas with poor sanitation and open defecation, leading to soil contamination.
  • Hookworm Species in India:
    • Both Ancylostoma duodenale and Necator americanus are prevalent, contributing to regional variation in disease severity and symptoms.
  • Control Strategies:
    • Requires integrated efforts, including:
      • Periodic mass deworming.
      • Improvement in sanitation and hygiene practices.
      • Health education to prevent reinfection.

Why Not Others?

  • A: Mass deworming alone cannot eradicate hookworm; reinfection occurs without sanitation and hygiene improvements.
  • B: Hookworm is primarily transmitted via skin penetration, not ingestion.
  • C: Necator americanus is also prevalent in India, making Ancylostoma duodenale not the sole species responsible.

Key Takeaways

  • Transmission route: Skin penetration of infective larvae from contaminated soil.
  • Main species in India: Ancylostoma duodenale and Necator americanus.
  • Control programs: Need deworming, sanitation, hygiene, and public education.
  • Chandler Index: A key tool for assessing the burden and success of intervention programs against hookworm infestation.

questions.text: Which of the following intravenous fluid is the best for treating a severe case of cholera?
questions.solution:
• Ringer Lactate (RL):
    • Closely resembles extracellular fluid (ECF), making it ideal for rapid rehydration.
    • Contains sodium, potassium, calcium, chloride, and lactate (metabolized into bicarbonate) to combat acidosis.
    • Essential for addressing the severe fluid loss, electrolyte imbalance, and acidosis in cholera patients.
    • Recommended by the WHO and other guidelines for severe dehydration due to cholera.

Why Not Other Options?

  • A. 5% Dextrose Solution:
    • Only supplies glucose for energy but lacks electrolytes needed to replace cholera-related losses.
    • Ineffective in addressing dehydration or metabolic acidosis.
  • B. Diarrhea Treatment Solution (ORS):
    • Designed for oral rehydration in mild to moderate cases.
    • Cannot restore fluid and electrolyte balance quickly enough in severe dehydration.
    • Not an intravenous fluid.
  • C. Normal Saline (NS):
    • Supplies sodium and chloride but lacks potassium, calcium, and bicarbonate.
    • Does not correct metabolic acidosis, a key complication in cholera.
    • Inferior to RL for comprehensive rehydration and electrolyte replacement.

Key Takeaways

  • Severe cholera requires rapid correction of dehydration, electrolyte loss, and acidosis.
  • Ringer Lactate: Superior option for IV rehydration due to its balanced composition and ability to correct metabolic disturbances.
  • Other fluids like NS or ORS lack critical components or are less effective in managing severe cases.

choices.text: 2 doses 1 month apart as .05-.07 ml/kg body weight
Best result are obtained when first dose given within 6 hours

questions.text: All the following are correct about use of hepatitis B immunoglobulin (HBIG) EXCEPT
questions.solution:
• Not later than 48 hours: HBIG is most effective when given within 48 hours of exposure and should not be delayed beyond 7 days.
  • 2 doses 1 month apart as 0.05-0.07 ml/kg body weight: The standard protocol for HBIG involves a single dose at 0.06 ml/kg body weight, given intramuscularly within 48 hours of exposure.
  • Best results are obtained when the first dose is given within 6 hours: The effectiveness is highest when HBIG is administered within 6 hours of exposure.
  • In case surface antigen positive, full course be started immediately:
    • For exposure to an HBsAg-positive source, both HBIG and the first dose of the hepatitis B vaccine should be administered immediately.
    • The full vaccine series (3 doses) is completed over several months, not "started immediately" in one go.

Why Not Other Options?

  • Not later than 48 hours: Timely administration ensures maximum efficacy in neutralizing the virus. Delayed administration reduces effectiveness.
  • 2 doses 1 month apart as 0.05–0.07 ml/kg body weight: Incorrect dosing protocol. Only one dose of HBIG is recommended.
  • Best results are obtained when the first dose is given within 6 hours: Early administration ensures higher protection by neutralizing the virus at the exposure site.
  • Full course be started immediately: Incorrect as vaccination is phased. Immediate focus is on administering HBIG + 1st vaccine dose.

Key Takeaways

  • HBIG: Must be administered within 48 hours, preferably within 6 hours.
  • Standard Protocol: Single dose of HBIG + 1st hepatitis B vaccine dose (followed by a full vaccination schedule).
  • The "full course" of vaccination cannot be "immediately started" but progresses over months.

choices.text: Sensitivity increases when all AFP cases are included
Specificity increases when all AFP cases are included
It removes the burden of confirming diagnosis from surveillance staff
Operational indicator to assess the performance of health staff

questions.text: Following are the logics for adoption of AFP surveillance in Polio EXCEPT
questions.solution:
• Sensitivity increases when all AFP cases are included: Including all cases of Acute Flaccid Paralysis (AFP) enhances the sensitivity of the surveillance system, ensuring even rare cases of polio are detected.
  • Specificity increases when all AFP cases are included: Specificity refers to the ability to identify those without the disease. Including all AFP cases may result in some non-polio AFP cases being misclassified as polio, thus reducing specificity.
  • It removes the burden of confirming diagnosis from surveillance staff: Including all AFP cases in surveillance reduces the pressure on healthcare workers to confirm a diagnosis for each suspected polio case.
  • Operational indicator to assess the performance of health staff: AFP surveillance serves as a key operational indicator, helping assess how well health staff are identifying and reporting AFP cases, which is vital for monitoring polio elimination efforts.

Key Takeaways

  • Increased Sensitivity: Including all AFP cases helps improve sensitivity in detecting polio.
  • Reduced Burden on Staff: Broadening surveillance eases the workload of confirming diagnoses.
  • Operational Indicator: AFP surveillance helps monitor the efficiency of health staff in reporting cases.

choices.text: It provides both local and circulating immunity
It has better sero conversion rate
It may also cause vaccine induced poliomyelitis

questions.text: All the following regarding the oral polio vaccine are correct EXCEPT
questions.solution:
• It provides both local and circulating immunity: Correct. The oral polio vaccine (OPV) induces both local immunity in the gut and circulating immunity in the bloodstream, making it highly effective at preventing polio transmission.
  • It is less expensive: Correct. OPV is generally more cost-effective compared to inactivated polio vaccine (IPV), which makes it a preferred choice for mass immunization campaigns.
  • It has better seroconversion rate: Incorrect. OPV does not have a better seroconversion rate compared to IPV. IPV usually provides a more consistent seroconversion rate in terms of inducing strong antibody responses, whereas OPV relies on mucosal immunity.
  • It may also cause vaccine-induced poliomyelitis: Correct. Vaccine-derived poliovirus (VDPV), a rare side effect of OPV, can cause vaccine-induced poliomyelitis in immunocompromised individuals or in settings where vaccination coverage is low.

Key Takeaways

  • OPV Advantages: OPV is cost-effective, induces both local and circulating immunity.
  • Seroconversion: IPV has a better seroconversion rate than OPV.
  • Vaccine-induced Poliomyelitis: OPV can cause vaccine-induced poliomyelitis, especially in areas with poor vaccine coverage.

choices.text: Coverage of pregnant women with tetanus toxoids
Community based surveillance of neonatal deaths

questions.text: Interventions for elimination of neonatal tetanus includes all EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Coverage of pregnant women with tetanus toxoids: Correct. Vaccinating pregnant women with tetanus toxoid prevents maternal and neonatal tetanus, as antibodies are passed from the mother to the newborn, providing passive immunity.
  • Safe delivery with disposable kits: Correct. Safe childbirth practices-such as using sterile and disposable delivery kits-are crucial to prevent neonatal tetanus, which is often caused by contamination during delivery or cutting the umbilical cord with unsterile instruments.
  • Community-based surveillance of neonatal deaths: Correct. Monitoring neonatal deaths and identifying the causes, such as neonatal tetanus, helps improve the targeting and effectiveness of prevention programs.
  • Primary vaccination of infants: Incorrect. While infant vaccination is important for general tetanus prevention, neonatal tetanus prevention focuses on maternal vaccination and safe delivery practices. Infant tetanus vaccination is not a direct intervention for eliminating neonatal tetanus but is important for preventing future cases of tetanus in childhood.

Key Takeaways

  • Neonatal tetanus elimination: Relies on maternal vaccination and safe childbirth practices.
  • Infant vaccination: Important for general tetanus prevention but does not directly target neonatal tetanus.
  • Surveillance: Vital for identifying cases and monitoring the success of interventions.

choices.text: It is negative in most children in first 6 months of life
It is an important aid to classify type of leprosy disease
BCG vaccination may convert lepra reaction from negative to positive

questions.text: Which of the following statements about lepromin test is not true?
questions.solution:
• It is negative in most children in the first 6 months of life: This is correct. Lepromin testing is typically negative in infants under 6 months because their immune system is not fully developed.
  • It is a diagnostic test: This is incorrect. The lepromin test is not a diagnostic test for leprosy. It is used to assess the immune response and help classify the type of leprosy (e.g., tuberculoid or lepromatous), not to diagnose the disease. Diagnosis is based on clinical evaluation and bacteriological examination.
  • It is an important aid to classify the type of leprosy disease: This is correct. The lepromin test helps classify leprosy into tuberculoid (positive reaction) and lepromatous (negative reaction) types, guiding treatment decisions.
  • BCG vaccination may convert lepra reaction from negative to positive: This is correct. BCG vaccination can stimulate the immune response, leading to a positive reaction in individuals who were initially negative for the lepromin test, especially in those who are susceptible to leprosy.

Key Takeaways

  • Lepromin test: Used primarily for classifying leprosy based on the immune response, not for diagnosis .It also tells about prognosis -positive test indicates good prognosis.
  • Not a diagnostic tool: Leprosy diagnosis is based on clinical signs and bacteriological examination, not the lepromin test.
  • BCG vaccination: Can influence the immune system, potentially turning a negative lepromin test result to positive.

questions.text: Which one does not qualify as bridge population under HIV control?
questions.solution:
• Truckers: Truckers are part of the bridge population due to their high mobility and frequent interactions with high-risk groups (HRG), such as commercial sex workers. This increases their risk of contracting and spreading HIV.
  • Migrant workers: Migrant workers also qualify as a bridge population. Their mobility and interactions with high-risk environments make them a link between HRGs (e.g., sex workers) and the general population, raising their risk for HIV transmission.
  • Out of school youth: Out of school youth are not typically classified as part of the bridge population. While they may be vulnerable to HIV infection, they are not considered intermediaries between HRGs and the general population, which is the defining characteristic of the bridge population.
  • Clients of HRG: Clients of HRGs, such as those engaging with sex workers, are part of the bridge population because they can contract HIV from HRGs and pass it to the general population, making them a key vector in the spread of HIV.

Key Takeaways

  • Bridge population: Individuals who connect high-risk groups (HRGs) with the general population, increasing the potential for HIV spread.
  • Truckers, migrant workers, and clients of HRGs are part of the bridge population, while out of school youth are not.

questions.text: Term included in NACP (National AIDS Control Programme) includes all EXCEPT
questions.solution:
• Targeted interventions: These are an essential part of the National AIDS Control Programme (NACP), focusing on high-risk groups (HRGs) such as sex workers, injecting drug users, and men who have sex with men (MSM) to reduce HIV transmission.
  • Community-based organizations: These organizations are integral to the NACP. They help implement targeted interventions and offer support to communities affected by HIV/AIDS through outreach, education, and services.
  • Drop-in centres: These centres are part of the NACP's strategy to provide safe spaces where high-risk populations can access health services, counselling, and support, promoting HIV prevention and care.
  • Directly observed treatment (DOT): This is a tuberculosis control strategy and is not used within the scope of HIV/AIDS management in NACP. DOT involves observing patients take their TB medication, which is not a core component of HIV treatment under NACP.

Key Takeaways

  • NACP focuses on targeted interventions, community-based organizations, and drop-in centers for effective HIV prevention and care.
  • Directly observed treatment (DOT) is related to TB control, not HIV management under NACP.

questions.text: Composition of meal under this activity:
questions.solution:
• The Mid Day Meal (MDM) program is a crucial nutrition intervention aimed at improving the health and learning outcomes of schoolchildren across India.
  • Nutritional Guidelines:
    • For primary school children (Classes 1-5): 450 calories and 12 grams of protein.
    • For upper primary children (Classes 6-8): 700 calories and 20 grams of protein.
    • The inclusion of micronutrients like iron, folic acid, and vitamin A is critical in addressing malnutrition and anemia.
  • Meal Composition typically ensures:
    • 1/2 protein: Derived from pulses, dairy products, or egg (if included).
    • 1/3 calorie: Provided through cereals like rice or wheat and vegetables.
    • The inclusion of vegetables and oil helps in achieving the right fat content and vitamins.

Why Not Others:

  • a. 1/2 protein; 1/2 calorie: This would result in an excess of calories, which doesn't align with the MDM's objective of balancing protein and calories for growth and health.
  • c. 1/3 protein; 1/3 calorie: An equal distribution would not meet the nutritional needs of the children, underestimating the importance of protein in child growth.
  • d. 1/3 protein; 1/2 calorie: This would be calorically excessive and protein-deficient, which would not meet the growth and cognitive needs of children.

Key Takeaways:

  • The MDM program is designed to provide a balanced and nutritious meal to promote physical growth and mental development.
  • The meal typically contains 1/2 protein and 1/3 calorie, with the goal of combating malnutrition and enhancing school retention and attendance.
  • The inclusion of micronutrients addresses common deficiencies like iron and vitamin A to improve overall health outcomes.

questions.text: Main worker of this programme:
questions.solution:
• The National Rural Health Mission (NRHM), launched in 2005, aimed to improve healthcare in rural India.
  • Main worker under NRHM: ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist) plays a pivotal role in providing essential health services at the grassroots level.
    • Role of ASHA: They are trained to deliver basic healthcare services, such as maternal and child health, family planning, immunization, and the prevention of diseases like tuberculosis and malaria.
  • ASHAs serve as a bridge between the healthcare system and the rural community, ensuring community participation and promoting health education and awareness.

Why Not Others:

  • a. Anganwadi- ICDS: Anganwadi workers focus on child development and nutrition services under the Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) scheme, not healthcare delivery.
  • c. MPW-M- NVBDCP: MPWs (Male Health Workers) work under NVBDCP (National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme) for vector-borne disease control, but they are not the main workers in NRHM.
  • d. MPW-F- NHFWP: MPW-F (Female Health Workers) under the National Family Welfare Program (NHFWP) focus on maternal health, but ASHAs have a broader role in NRHM.

Key Takeaways:

  • ASHAs are the main workers in NRHM, delivering health services in rural areas and acting as a link between healthcare providers and communities.
  • NRHM aims to enhance rural healthcare, focusing on maternal, child health, and disease prevention.

choices.text: Implemented by Ministry of Women & Child Development
It provides a cover of Rs. 5 lakhs per family per year for secondary and tertiary care hospitalization across public and private empanelled hospitals in India.
NITI Aayog has played a critical role in shaping the above health scheme.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is not true about the health scheme represented by above logo?
questions.solution:
• The POSHAN Abhiyaan (Prime Minister's Overarching Scheme for Holistic Nourishment) was launched in 2018 to address malnutrition and improve the nutritional outcomes for children, adolescents, pregnant women, and lactating mothers.
  • It is a people's movement (Jan Andolan) aimed at improving health and nutrition through technology, targeted interventions, and community participation.
  • Key features of POSHAN Abhiyaan:
    • Launched by Prime Minister Modi on International Women's Day, 8th March 2018.
    • Implemented by the Ministry of Women & Child Development, focusing on nutrition and health.
    • Convergence with various stakeholders like local bodies, social organizations, and both the public and private sectors.
    • NITI Aayog has played a significant role in shaping the strategic framework for POSHAN Abhiyaan.

Key Takeaways:

  • POSHAN Abhiyaan focuses on improving nutritional outcomes rather than providing hospitalization benefits.
  • The scheme emphasizes community participation, technology, and inclusive approach to combat malnutrition.

choices.text: > 10% population of known HIV+ve among TB patients tested for HIV in the district
> 12% population of known HIV+ve among TB patients tested for HIV in the district
>15% population of known HIV+ve among TB patients tested for HIV in the district

questions.text: As per the NTEP, high priority TB- HIV District is defined as
questions.solution:
• NTEP (National Tuberculosis Elimination Program) in India aims to eliminate tuberculosis (TB) by focusing on various aspects, including TB-HIV co-infection.
  • A high priority TB-HIV district is defined based on the proportion of HIV-positive patients among those with TB:
    • More than 10% of TB patients tested for HIV in the district are HIV-positive.
  • This categorization helps prioritize resources and interventions in areas with a higher burden of both TB and HIV, improving the integration of TB and HIV services.

NTEP CAREGORISATION OF DISTRICTS

Key Takeaways:

  • A high-priority TB-HIV district under NTEP is identified if > 10% of TB patients tested for HIV are HIV-positive.
  • This prioritization allows targeted efforts for better TB-HIV co-management and resource allocation.

questions.text: Disease not screened under Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK):
questions.solution:
• Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK) is a program designed for the early identification and management of health conditions in children, focusing on the 4 Ds:
    • Defects at birth
    • Deficiencies
    • Diseases
    • Developmental delays and disabilities
  • It aims to screen children for various conditions, including birth defects, deficiencies (e.g., Vitamin A), diseases, and developmental delays, but does not specifically target Congenital Glaucoma.
  • Congenital Glaucoma is typically identified and managed through specialized ophthalmic care, but is not directly screened under RBSK.

Why Not Others:

  • A. Vitamin A deficiency: This condition is addressed under the RBSK program through screening and supplementation, as it falls under deficiencies.
  • C. Congenital cataract: This is a defect at birth and is screened under RBSK as part of the birth defects category.
  • D. Retinopathy of prematurity: This is screened under RBSK in preterm infants to detect eye issues that could lead to blindness.

Key Takeaways:

  • RBSK focuses on screening for birth defects, nutritional deficiencies, diseases, and developmental delays.
  • Congenital glaucoma is not a part of the routine screening under this program.

choices.text: 60mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of Folic acid daily once
60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid weekly once
60 mg of elemental iron and 400 mcg of folic acid daily once
60 mg of elemental iron and 400 mcg of folic acid weekly once

questions.text: Dose of IFA tablet for adolescent girl under Anemia Mukt Bharat:
questions.solution:
• The Anemia Mukt Bharat (AMB) initiative aims to reduce the prevalence of anemia among adolescents in India.
  • For adolescent girls, the recommended dose of Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) is 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid, administered once a week. This regimen helps prevent and treat iron-deficiency anemia, which is prevalent among adolescent girls.
  • Weekly supplementation is preferred as it improves adherence and ensures effective prevention and management of anemia.

Key Takeaways:

  • The correct dose under Anemia Mukt Bharat for adolescent girls is 60 mg of iron and 500 mcg of folic acid weekly.
  • This approach aims to reduce anemia through effective supplementation while ensuring better compliance.

ANAEMIA MUKT BHARAT PROGRAMME (AMB)

For adolescent girls, 60 mg elemental iron and 500µg folic acid is given, weekly once.

Reference: https://anemiamuktbharat.info/interventions/

questions.text: Which of the following agency provide Seed and manure in Applied Nutrition programme?
questions.solution:
• The Applied Nutrition Programme (ANP) was introduced in 1962 to improve nutrition at the grassroots level by encouraging communities to grow nutritious foods locally.
  • UNICEF has been actively involved in this initiative by providing essential resources such as seeds, manure, implements, and water supply equipment to boost food production at the local level.
  • School gardens are a key aspect of the programme, where locally grown nutritious food can be used in school feeding schemes or for nutrition education.
  • The primary aim of ANP is to ensure self-reliance in food production for vulnerable groups such as children (3-6 years), pregnant, and lactating mothers.
  • The programme promotes activities like kitchen gardening, poultry farming, horticulture, and beekeeping, contributing to local nutritional improvement.
  • ANP is a community-driven initiative, where local residents are encouraged to actively participate in food production for their consumption, leading to long-term sustainability.

Why Not Others:

  • A. CARE: Although CARE works in the field of nutrition and food security, it is not directly involved in providing seeds or manure under the ANP.
  • C. WHO: WHO works on global health strategies, disease prevention, and policies but does not directly engage in local food production efforts like the ANP.
  • D. UNDP: UNDP focuses on broader development goals but does not specifically target nutritional interventions like the provision of seeds and manure.

Key Takeaways:

  • UNICEF plays a central role in the Applied Nutrition Programme, especially through the provision of seeds, manure, and other agricultural inputs.
  • The programme encourages community participation in food production, focusing on self-reliance to improve nutrition outcomes.
  • Key activities include poultry farming, kitchen gardening, and nutrition education, which target the nutritional needs of children and mothers.

Reference: https://www.nin.res.in/academics/notifications/Prospectus%20MSc%20(AN)%20&%20(SN)%20-%202021-23.pdf,

questions.text: School health is the responsibility of
questions.solution:
• School health services are primarily administered by the Primary Health Centre (PHC), which is tasked with providing comprehensive healthcare services to rural communities.
  • PHCs focus on preventive, promotive, curative, and rehabilitative health care, making them central to the delivery of school health services in rural and semi-rural areas.
  • A whole-time medical officer at the PHC is responsible for overseeing school health programs, which cater to 5,000 to 6,000 children annually.
  • The School Health Committee recommends strengthening PHCs by adding more staff to effectively implement school health services across larger populations.

Why Not Others:

  • A. Sub-centre: While sub-centres play a role in community-level health services, they are not typically responsible for comprehensive school health programs, which require more resources.
  • C. Sub-district hospital: Sub-district hospitals primarily focus on curative healthcare and are not involved in preventive services like school health.
  • D. District hospital: District hospitals provide specialized care and do not handle school health services, which are under the purview of PHCs.

Key Takeaways:

  • PHCs are the main healthcare providers for school health services, delivering preventive and curative care to students.
  • The School Health Programme, introduced under Ayushman Bharat in 2018, designates teachers and children as Health and Wellness Ambassadors and Messengers, respectively.
  • Health and Wellness Days are held regularly in schools to promote health awareness among children.

Services given by school health:

questions.text: A 12 year old girl not registered in any school is undergoing malnutrition, she has low Hb and belongs to low socioeconomic status. Under which of the following program/scheme will this girl get nutritional benefit?
questions.solution:
• ICDS (Integrated Child Development Services) is a comprehensive program that focuses on the nutritional and health needs of children, pregnant women, and lactating mothers. It provides:
    • Supplementary nutrition to children who are malnourished.
    • Health check-ups, immunization, and growth monitoring.
    • Programs targeting adolescent girls (e.g., Kishori Shakti Yojana) are also part of ICDS, helping to address nutritional deficits and promote health awareness.
    • The ICDS services extend to children in the community, even if they are not enrolled in school, making it applicable for this 12-year-old girl.

Why Not Others:

  • Mid Day Meal (B): This program is specifically designed for school-going children. It provides hot cooked meals to children enrolled in government and government-aided schools to tackle malnutrition. Since the girl is not attending school, she is not eligible for this scheme.
  • JSSY (C): The Janani Shishu Suraksha Yojana focuses primarily on improving maternal and child health, with a focus on pregnant women, newborns, and infants. It does not provide the nutritional support that this 12-year-old girl needs at her age.
  • RBSK (D): The Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram is a health screening and early intervention program. While it helps in identifying health issues like malnutrition, it is primarily focused on early detection and treatment of health conditions rather than providing ongoing nutritional support. It also does not directly address the socioeconomic factors impacting nutrition in children.

Key Takeaways:

  • ICDS provides comprehensive support to children for nutritional care, health monitoring, and education, which makes it the best option for this 12-year-old girl.
  • Other programs like Mid Day Meal and RBSK have specific eligibility criteria (e.g., school enrollment and health screenings) that exclude this child, while JSSY is more focused on maternal and infant care.

Reference: https://wcd.nic.in/kishori-shakti-yojana/

questions.text: S in the SAFE strategy of trachoma stands for?
questions.solution:
• The "S" in the SAFE strategy for trachoma stands for Surgery. The SAFE strategy is a comprehensive approach to control and eliminate trachoma, which is a major cause of blindness. It includes:
    • Surgery (tertiary prevention) to correct advanced stages like trichiasis and entropion.
    • Antibiotics (secondary prevention) to treat and prevent infection.
    • Facial cleanliness (primary prevention) to reduce the transmission of the infection.
    • Environmental changes (primordial prevention) to reduce the spread of disease through improved sanitation.

SAFE Strategy Components:

  • S: Surgery - Tertiary prevention for correcting trichiasis and entropion.
  • A: Antibiotics - Azithromycin (single dose) or tetracycline ointment for preventing and treating the infection.
  • F: Facial hygiene - Primary prevention through promoting clean faces to reduce transmission.
  • E: Environmental improvement - Improving sanitation and eliminating flies that transmit the disease.

Key Takeaways:

  • The "S" in the SAFE strategy stands for Surgery, which is crucial for advanced stages of trachoma.
  • The SAFE strategy combines surgery, antibiotics, facial cleanliness, and environmental changes to control and prevent trachoma.
